title: Please admit the Khazix buff was only because his new skin is coming out
body:
It's so painfully obvious; he never needed a buff in the first place and it's 100% out of the blue. Also it's on his W slow amount (which is probably the thing least affected by buffs), an obscure value that can give Kha some boosted playrates and buyrates.


Nobody buy this skin. Please protest this shit

replies.body:
Maple Nectar commented on this via Twitter when a player asked a similar question:
https://twitter.com/RiotMapleNectar/status/1044664008949690368

It's primarily a pro play focused buff because we felt that Kha'Zix is on the verge of competitive viability with small room to grow in solo queue (he was sitting at 48-49% WR according to our internal data before the buffs). W evolve Kha'Zix (prior to the stint Kha'Zix had with R evolve first earlier this season) has seen play historically and was likely the way to go for a buff to avoid negatively impacting players.

But in all honesty if people actually understood how Yorick worked he wouldn't need the nerf in the first place. Riot nerfed him due to low elo win rate, but it slaughtered his high elo win rate instead. One of the reasons why Yorick looks insanely strong is that he's picked into champions he directly counters hard, such as Darius, Urgot, Garen, GP...you seem smart, so you get the idea. 

tl;dr you beat them in lane due to how your kit works in the matchup, then you split push because its the top laner's job to split, but theirs is made irrelevant, assuming you won lane that is.

With said nerf into play, he doesn't really win those matchups unless they horribly misplay. That's bad: If he can't even get a sizable lead via proper play vs the champions he's meant to counter, there's no reason to pick him whatsoever. That singular change caused every high elo Yorick main to quit playing the champion until something can be done about it: it doesn't feel good whatsoever to waste 30-40s to set up graves until lv 3, only to discover the ghouls barely even tickle the enemy laner, while you get obliterated by almost everyone in lane.

Riot themselves also admitted that they missed the ballpark on a recent reply to a Yorick OTP, and had considered doing it *again*.

As for your argument, you aren't completely wrong: he's a dedicated split pusher, but that's due to triforce being a split pusher's first item. All he really has is his Q bonk and his ghouls. Compare that to a Nasus who presses R on a tower: he'd shred that shit quickly with his reduced Q cd. 

But that's just soloQ shit you see here and there. If you watched the lcs games with Yorick, you'd see that he was really just csing and killing GP/Kindred only one time each (the double kill in particular). He didn't seem strong at all, but one misplay GGS did made Yorick come back and win the game.

But that's exactly my point. I'm not saying he's OP now. I'm saying if we ever want him to be competitive viable(and not just a niche pick used to try to surprise the opponent to get a single win for a team who has practiced it), they'd need to either adjust his kit to make him less one-dimensional OR overpower him to such a degree that him being one-dimensional no longer matters. (and ya, Nasus is in the same boat)

Uncoordinated teams aren't able to punish that type of telegraphing, but coordinated teams ARE. So if you're revealing your entire strategy that early, the pieces of that strategy have to be insanely strong in order for them to not get countered by coordinated teams. And if they're strong enough to not be countered by coordinated teams, then they're going to be even STRONGER against uncoordinated teams. Which means if they're viable in competitive, they're almost certainly overpowered outside of that environment.

So I know this is about Kha'zix, but this brings me to a question I saw on the board also...


Why was Wukong nerfed so hard then? He was played competitively (Caps mid) although with a higher winrate (~54% at an 4% play rate vs ~49% at 8% according to lolalytics). His burst was high, but his nerfs completely gutted him and left him out of pro play for sure. He is not a champion that performs well at high elo, as I believe there are currently no Challenger Wukong players in NA. There previously was one, LOL Harambe, who is no longer able to maintain that level elo with the nerfs.

I'm not sure if lolalytics is a reliable source of statistics, especially compared to your internal data. After the nerfs, I believe Wukongs win rate did not change that much, but his play rate halved. When the sample size is so small, is the data as reliable? I'm not saying somebody should be able to pick up a champion and perform well, but if the majority of Wukong players are OTP, is that a fair comparison to a champion with double the play rate? I think win rate is a little tricky for a champion like Wukong, who is played rarely compared to other champions. If Wukong is picked 4% of the time, with a 12% mid lane play rate, is a 53% win rate really indicative of how the champion is performing? 

I understand his burst was too high, but it was said he'd be buffed in a way to increase tankiness, regen, sustain damage, etc. That resulted in an 8% attack speed buff (not to the ratio), which doesn't seem like enough to pick him over other junglers. But I feel like the reason why he is "bad" now, is because he is worse in multiple aspects compared to other champions, who haven't been addressed. Graves has a 20% play rate with a 52% win rate... That seems a lot more indicative of an over powered champion. 

I hope this clarifies why I was a bit confused about Wukong. I don't mean to come off as argumentative, I just feel like the Wukong nerfs were way too harsh, especially when compared to other champions. Graves is tankier, has a better early game, and can output a lot of damage. It just feels like since Wukong is hard to balance, he was gutted.

That's why I said, with such a low play rate, is his win rate really indicative of how strong of a champion he is. The sample size is not large enough. It's a lazy way to say that a champion is performing well and doesn't give enough context to his overall performance.
